input: What are OTP cards and how do they work?
output: OTP cards are a type of security product that generates a new password each time a user logs in. One example of an OTP product is the SecurID card from RSA Security. This card is a device that displays a new password to the user periodically, typically every 60 seconds. When a user needs to log into a computer system, they enter the number shown on the card when prompted by the server. The server is aware of the algorithm the SecurID card uses to generate passwords and can verify the password entered by the user. Some OTP systems generate passwords only when a personal identification number (PIN) is entered. While OTP systems traditionally required separate devices, they are now often integrated into personal digital assistants (PDAs) and cell phones.

input: What are smart cards?
output: Smart cards are a type of security device. Newer generations of smart cards are designed to be tamper-resistant. This means that if an unauthorized person attempts to open the card or access the information stored on it, the internal circuitry of the card will self-destruct. The core functionality of a smart card, its 'smart' part, is composed of a microprocessor, memory, and other components that are epoxied or glued together. This construction makes it difficult to disassemble the card and access its components.
